modules.title: Password Protection
modules.subtitle: Learn to create and manage strong passwords

lessons.title: Why Strong Passwords Matter
lessons.content: Passwords are your first line of defense against cybercriminals. A strong password can be the difference between keeping your accounts safe and having your identity stolen.

lessons.title: Creating Strong Passwords
lessons.content: Learn the essential rules for creating passwords that are both secure and memorable.

tips.title: Use at least 12-16 characters
tips.description: Longer passwords are exponentially harder to crack

tips.title: Mix character types
tips.description: Combine uppercase, lowercase, numbers, and symbols

tips.title: Use unique passwords
tips.description: Never reuse passwords across different accounts

lessons.title: Australian Example
lessons.content: Instead of "password123", try "KangarooJumping2025!Sydney" - it's long, memorable, and includes Australian references that are meaningful to you.

lessons.title: Password Managers
lessons.content: Password managers generate and store unique passwords for all your accounts.

lessons.title: What NOT to Do
lessons.content: Common password mistakes that put you at risk.
items: Don't use personal information (birthdays, names, addresses)
Don't use common words or patterns
Don't write passwords on sticky notes

lessons.title: What is Phishing?
lessons.content: Phishing is when criminals send fake emails or texts pretending to be from legitimate companies to steal your personal information, passwords, or money.

lessons.title: Warning Signs to Look For
lessons.content: Learn to spot the red flags that indicate a message is a scam.

signs.title: Urgent language
signs.description: 'Act now!' 'Your account will be closed!' 'Immediate action required!'

signs.title: Generic greetings
signs.description: 'Dear Customer' instead of your actual name

signs.title: Suspicious links
signs.description: Hover over links to see where they really go

lessons.title: Australian Example
lessons.content: "Your ATO tax refund is ready! Click here to claim $1,247.50 immediately or it will expire in 24 hours." Red flags: The ATO doesn't send refund notifications via email, uses urgent language, and asks you to click links.

lessons.title: How to Verify Suspicious Messages
lessons.content: Steps to take when you receive a suspicious message.
steps: Contact the company directly using official phone numbers
Log into your account through the official website (not email links)
Check the sender's email address carefully for misspellings
Ask yourself: "Was I expecting this message?"

lessons.title: What to Do if You've Been Targeted
lessons.content: Immediate actions to take if you suspect you've been targeted by a scam.
actions: Don't click any links or download attachments
Report the message to the company being impersonated
Forward phishing emails to the ACCC's Scamwatch
If you clicked a link, change your passwords immediately

modules.title: Device & Home Security
modules.subtitle: Secure your devices and home network

lessons.title: Why Device Security Matters
lessons.content: Your devices contain personal photos, banking apps, emails, and more. Securing them protects your entire digital life.

lessons.title: Computer Security
lessons.content: Essential steps to keep your computer secure.

tips.title: Keep software updated
tips.description: Enable automatic updates for your operating system and apps

tips.title: Use antivirus software
tips.description: Windows Defender is built-in and effective for most users

tips.title: Enable firewall
tips.description: Your computer's firewall blocks unauthorized access

lessons.title: Home Wi-Fi Security
lessons.content: Protect your home network from unauthorized access.
steps: Use WPA3 encryption (or at least WPA2)
Set up a guest network for visitors

lessons.title: Backup Your Data
lessons.content: Follow the 3-2-1 rule: 3 copies of important data, on 2 different types of media, with 1 copy stored offsite (like cloud storage).

lessons.title: Public Wi-Fi Safety
lessons.content: How to stay safe when using public Wi-Fi networks.
items: Avoid accessing sensitive accounts on public Wi-Fi
Turn off auto-connect to Wi-Fi networks
Use your phone's hotspot instead when possible

modules.title: Social Media & Privacy
modules.subtitle: Protect your privacy on social platforms

lessons.title: Your Digital Footprint
lessons.content: Everything you post online creates a permanent digital footprint. Even "private" posts can become public through data breaches or account compromises.

lessons.title: Privacy Settings
lessons.content: How to control who can see your social media content.

tips.title: Review privacy settings regularly
tips.description: Social media platforms often change their privacy policies

tips.title: Limit who can see your posts
tips.description: Set posts to 'Friends only' rather than 'Public'

tips.title: Control who can find you
tips.description: Limit search visibility and friend requests

lessons.title: What Not to Share
lessons.content: Information that should never be shared on social media.

lessons.title: Think Before You Post
lessons.content: Ask yourself: "Would I be comfortable if my employer, family, or a stranger saw this?" If not, don't post it.

lessons.title: Recognizing Social Media Scams
lessons.content: Common scams that target social media users.
items: Fake friend requests from people you already know
Requests for money from "friends" in trouble

lessons.title: Your Phone is a Computer
lessons.content: Modern smartphones contain more personal information than most computers. They need the same level of security protection.

lessons.title: Basic Phone Security
lessons.content: Fundamental security measures for your mobile device.

tips.title: Use a strong lock screen
tips.description: PIN, password, fingerprint, or face recognition

tips.title: Keep your OS updated
tips.description: Enable automatic updates for security patches

tips.title: Enable remote wipe
tips.description: So you can erase your phone if it's lost or stolen

lessons.title: App Safety Tips
lessons.content: How to safely download and use mobile apps.
steps: Only download apps from official stores (Google Play, Apple App Store)
Regularly review and uninstall unused apps
Be cautious with apps requesting excessive permissions

lessons.title: Real-world Example: SIM Swapping
lessons.content: Sarah received a text saying her Telstra service would be suspended. She called Telstra directly and discovered it was a scam. The criminals were trying to get her to provide information that could be used for SIM swapping - taking control of her phone number.

lessons.title: Warning Signs of Phone Scams
lessons.content: Red flags that indicate a phone scam.
items: Calls claiming to be from tech support
Sudden loss of phone service (possible SIM swap)

lessons.title: Mobile Device Security
lessons.content: Advanced security measures for mobile devices.
steps: Use two-factor authentication on important accounts
Don't leave your phone unattended in public
Consider using a VPN for sensitive activities
